concepts.unlisted_description: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: certified the case under Art. 133 1 c as a fit one for appeal to this Court. In this appeal, two principal contentions fall to be determined, viz., (1) whether legislative authority was conferred upon the Military Governor by the Farman dated September 19, 1948 and (2) If, by the Farman, legislative authority was delegated to the Military Governor, whether it was circumscribed by any limitations or reservations.

anchor.surface_text: Arts. 31 A and 31 B and Sch. IX were incorporated in the Constitution. The Abolition Regulation and the Commutation Regulation were included in Schedule IX and by virtue of Art. 31 B, neither the Regulations nor any of the provisions thereof were to be deemed to be void or ever to have become void on the ground that the Regulations were inconsistent with or took away or abridged any of the rights conferred by any of the provisions of Part III of the Constitution.

by virtue of Art. 31 B, neither the Regulations nor any of the provisions thereof were to be deemed to be void or ever to have become void on the ground that the Regulations were inconsistent with or took away or abridged any of the rights conferred by any of the provisions of Part III of the Constitution. In the meantime, the appellant had, on January 29, 1951, filed a petition in the High Court of Hyderabad for a writ in the nature of mandamus directing the State of Hyderabad and the Jagir Administrator to hand over possession of the appellants properties and for an order declaring the Abolition Regulation and the Commutation Regulation ultra vires and unconstitutional and for certain interim orders.

concepts.unlisted_description: Invalidity of laws enacted to evade constitutional limits

anchor.surface_text: The doctrine of invalidity of legislative provisions enacted in colourable exercise of authority applies to legislatures whose powers are subject to constitutional restrictions. When such a legislative body seeks, under the guise or pretence of complying with the restrictions, in enacting a statute, to evade or elude them, it is but a fraud on the Constitution, and the statute is liable to be declared invalid on the ground that the enactment is in colourable exercise of authority, the statute being in truth beyond the competence of the body. But a statute enacted by a legislative authority whose powers are not fettered by any constitutional or other limitations, cannot be declared invalid as enacted in colourable exercise of its powers.

concepts.unlisted_description: Fraud on Constitution by evading limits

anchor.surface_text: The Constitution has except as otherwise expressly provided, no retrospective operation Keshavan Madhava Menon v. State of Bombay 1 and rights which were by legislation extinguished, before it was enacted, are not revived thereby. At the commencement of the Constitution, the appellant had, therefore, no rights in the jagirs and he, obviously, could not claim a writ of mandamus directing delivery of possession of the jagir, or a writ directing commutation otherwise than under the provisions of the Commutation Regulation.

issues.text: whether legislative authority was conferred upon the Military Governor by the Farman dated September 19, 1948

anchor.surface_text: (1) whether legislative authority was conferred upon the Military Governor by the Farman dated September 19, 1948 and (2) If, by the Farman, legislative authority was delegated to the Military Governor, whether it was circumscribed by any limitations or reservations.

issues.text: If, by the Farman, legislative authority was delegated to the Military Governor, whether it was circumscribed by any limitations or reservations

anchor.surface_text: (2) If, by the Farman, legislative authority was delegated to the Military Governor, whether it was circumscribed by any limitations or reservations. Was the Military Governor, by the Farman dated September 19, 1948, invested with all the sovereign authority legislative, executive and judicial of H.E.H. the Nizam or was he merely invested with the executive authority ?

issues.text: Was the Military Governor, by the Farman dated September 19, 1948, invested with all the sovereign authority legislative, executive and judicial of H.E.H. the Nizam or was he merely invested with the executive authority

anchor.surface_text: Was the Military Governor, by the Farman dated September 19, 1948, invested with all the sovereign authority legislative, executive and judicial of H.E.H. the Nizam or was he merely invested with the executive authority ? By the plain words used in the Farman, all authority for the administration of the State was conferred upon the Military Governor and there is nothing in the text of the Farman which warrants the view that only executive authority was intended to be delegated thereby.

issues.text: whether ss. 4(1)(c) and 4(2) of the Commutation Regulation and s. 6(4) of the Abolition Regulation were invalid because by these provisions, there was naked confiscation of the property of the appellant and that they amounted to colourable and fraudulent exercise of legislative power

anchor.surface_text: By this petition, the appellant claimed that ss. 4 1  c  and 4 2  of the Commutation Regulation and s. 6 4  of the Abolition Regulation were invalid because by these provisions, there was naked confiscation of the property of the appellant and that they amounted to colourable and fraudulent exercise of legislative power . The High Court of Hyderabad rejected the petition filed by the appellant, but certified the case under Art. 133 1  c  as a fit one for appeal to this Court.

issues.text: whether the fundamental rights of the appellant under the Constitution were infringed by the two Regulations

anchor.surface_text: The plea that the fundamental rights of the appellant under the Constitution were infringed by the two Regulations does not require any detailed examination. By virtue of the Abolition Regulation, the rights of the appellant as a jagirdar in his jagir were extinguished and by the Commutation Regulation, the quantum of compensation payable to him was determined by a pre-Constitution legislation.

issues.text: whether the Constitution operates retrospectively to revive the rights which had been extinguished before it was enacted

anchor.surface_text: The Constitution has except as otherwise expressly provided, no retrospective operation Keshavan Madhava Menon v. State of Bombay 1 and rights which were by legislation extinguished, before it was enacted, are not revived thereby. At the commencement of the Constitution, the appellant had, therefore, no rights in the jagirs and he, obviously, could not claim a writ of mandamus directing delivery of possession of the jagir, or a writ directing commutation otherwise than under the provisions of the Commutation Regulation.

arguments.claim: Same questions raised in Civil Appeal No. 686 of 1957 as in 392 of 1956

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 686 of 1957. This appeal raises the same question which has been decided in the companion Appeal No.

holdings.text: By the plain words used in the Farman, all authority for the administration of the State was conferred upon the Military Governor and there is nothing in the text of the Farman which warrants the view that only executive authority was intended to be delegated thereby. Within the expression, all administrative authority is encompassed the entirety of the authority of the sovereign, and by the delegation from His Exalted Highness the Nizam, the Military Governor was invested with that authority in all its amplitude.

anchor.surface_text: By the plain words used in the Farman, all authority for the administration of the State was conferred upon the Military Governor and there is numberhing in the text of the Farman which warrants the view that only executive authority was intended to be delegated thereby. Within the expression, all administrative authority is encompassed the entirety of the authority of the sovereign, and by the delegation from His Exalted Highness the Nizam, the Military Governor was invested with that authority in all its amplitude.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual interpretation of Farman terms 'all authority for the administration' encompasses full sovereign powers including legislative; no textual limit to executive only.

holdings.text: The Farman promulgated on September 19, 1948, by His Exalted Highness the Nizam delegated his sovereign authority to the Military Governor and to remove all doubts as to the effect of that delegation, an explanatory Farman dated August 7, 1949, was issued. It was declared in express terms by that Farman that the authority of the Military Governor included and has always included the authority to make Regulations.

anchor.surface_text: By the plain words used in the Farman, all authority for the administration of the State was conferred upon the Military Governor and there is nothing in the text of the Farman which warrants the view that only executive authority was intended to be delegated thereby. Within the expression, all administrative authority is encompassed the entirety of the authority of the sovereign, and by the delegation from His Exalted Highness the Nizam, the Military Governor was invested with that authority in all its amplitude.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explanatory Farman explicitly confirms that delegated authority always included power to make Regulations, harmonizing with original Farman.

holdings.text: There is, however, no evidence on the record to show that after September 19, 1948, and before the Abolition Regulation was promulgated, the authority of the Military Governor was withdrawn or that His Exalted Highness the Nizam had issued any order or Regulation inconsistent with the Abolition Regulation. Assuming that no opportunity had arisen for exercise of the sovereign authority in the matter of resumption of jagirs or extinction of the jagirdars interests before the promulgation of the Abolition Regulation, an inference cannot therefrom arise that His Exalted Highness the Nizam had irrevocably placed a restriction on his sovereignty, or that the delegation to the Military Governor of the sovereign authority was subject to an implied restriction.

anchor.surface_text: the legality of the action of the latter was not open to challenge on any test of legislative competence. Assuming that no opportunity had arisen for exercise of the sovereign authority in the matter of resumption of jagirs or extinction of the jagirdars interests before the promulgation of the Abolition Regulation, an inference cannot therefrom arise that His Exalted Highness the Nizam had irrevocably placed a restriction on his sovereignty, or that the delegation to the Military Governor of the sovereign authority was subject to an implied restriction that the interests of the jagirdars in the jagirs could not in exercise of the authority be extinguished.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of withdrawal or inconsistency; lack of prior exercise does not imply irrevocable restriction on sovereign power delegated without limits.

holdings.text: The doctrine of invalidity of legislative provisions enacted in colourable exercise of authority applies to legislatures whose powers are subject to constitutional restrictions. [...] But a statute enacted by a legislative authority whose powers are not fettered by any constitutional or other limitations, cannot be declared invalid as enacted in colourable exercise of its powers.

anchor.surface_text: The doctrine of invalidity of legislative provisions enacted in colourable exercise of authority applies to legislatures whose powers are subject to constitutional restrictions. When such a legislative body seeks, under the guise or pretence of complying with the restrictions, in enacting a statute, to evade or elude them, it is but a fraud on the Constitution, and the statute is liable to be declared invalid on the ground that the enactment is in colourable exercise of authority, the statute being in truth beyond the competence of the body. But a statute enacted by a legislative authority whose powers are not fettered by any constitutional or other limitations, cannot be declared invalid as enacted in colourable exercise of its powers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Colourable legislation doctrine limited to constitutionally restricted legislatures; Military Governor as sovereign delegate unfettered, so Abolition Regulation valid.

holdings.text: The authority of the Chief Minister under the Farman dated December 1, 1949, in its amplitude, was as extensive as that of His Exalted Highness the Nizam and the Commutation Regulation was not liable to be challenged on the ground of want of legislative competence or colourable exercise of legislative authority.

anchor.surface_text: The authority of the Chief Minister under the Farman dated December 1, 1949, in its amplitude, was as extensive as that of His Exalted Highness the Nizam and the Commutation Regulation was not liable to be challenged on the ground of want of legislative competence or colourable exercise of legislative authority

holdings.reasoning_summary: December 1, 1949 Farman transferred same full sovereign authority to Chief Minister previously held by Military Governor.

holdings.text: The Constitution has except as otherwise expressly provided, no retrospective operation Keshavan Madhava Menon v. State of Bombay and rights which were by legislation extinguished, before it was enacted, are not revived thereby.

anchor.surface_text: The Constitution has except as otherwise expressly provided, no retrospective operation Keshavan Madhava Menon v. State of Bombay 1 and rights which were by legislation extinguished, before it was enacted, are not revived thereby. At the commencement of the Constitution, the appellant had, therefore, no rights in the jagirs and he, obviously, could not claim a writ of mandamus directing delivery of possession of the jagir, or a writ directing commutation otherwise than under the provisions of the Commutation Regulation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedent, Constitution does not revive rights extinguished by valid pre-Constitution laws; appellant had no jagir rights at commencement.

holdings.text: It may also be observed that the Parliament has, by the Constitution 1st, Amendment Act, included the Abolition and the Commutation Regulations in the ninth schedule, and by virtue of Art. 31 B , the two Regulations are exempt from challenge on the ground that they are inconsistent with or take away or abridge any of the fundamental rights conferred by Part III of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It may also be observed that the Parliament has, by the Constitution 1st, Amendment Act, included the Abolition and the Commutation Regulations in the ninth schedule, and by virtue of Art. 31 B , the two Regulations are exempt from challenge on the ground that they are inconsistent with or take away or abridge any of the fundamental rights conferred by Part III of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Regulations listed in Ninth Schedule; Art. 31B expressly exempts from Part III challenge.

precedents.case_name: Keshavan Madhava Menon v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: The Constitution has no retrospective operation except as otherwise expressly provided and does not revive rights extinguished by legislation before its enactment

anchor.surface_text: By the plain words used in the Farman, all authority for the administration of the State was conferred upon the Military Governor and there is numberhing in the text of the Farman which warrants the view that only executive authority was intended to be delegated thereby. Within the expression, all administrative authority is encompassed the entirety of the authority of the sovereign, and by the delegation from His Exalted Highness the Nizam, the Military Governor was invested with that authority in all its amplitude.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with costs. Civil Appeal No. 686 of 1957. This appeal raises the same question which has been decided in the companion Appeal No.

anchor.surface_text: By the plain words used in the Farman, all authority for the administration of the State was conferred upon the Military Governor and there is nothing in the text of the Farman which warrants the view that only executive authority was intended to be delegated thereby. Within the expression, all administrative authority is encompassed the entirety of the authority of the sovereign, and by the delegation from His Exalted Highness the Nizam, the Military Governor was invested with that authority in all its amplitude.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with costs. Civil Appeal No. 686 of 1957. This appeal raises the same question which has been decided in the companion Appeal No.

The holding that no evidence exists of withdrawal or inconsistent orders addresses the issue of whether the legislative authority delegated by the Farman was circumscribed by limitations or reservations.

anchor.surface_text: the legality of the action of the latter was not open to challenge on any test of legislative competence. Assuming that no opportunity had arisen for exercise of the sovereign authority in the matter of resumption of jagirs or extinction of the jagirdars interests before the promulgation of the Abolition Regulation, an inference cannot therefrom arise that His Exalted Highness the Nizam had irrevocably placed a restriction on his sovereignty, or that the delegation to the Military Governor of the sovereign authority was subject to an implied restriction that the interests of the jagirdars in the jagirs could not in exercise of the authority be extinguished.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with costs. Civil Appeal No. 686 of 1957. This appeal raises the same question which has been decided in the companion Appeal No.

anchor.surface_text: ther limitations, cannot be declared invalid as enacted in companyourable exercise of its powers. The authority of the Chief Minister under the Farman

edges.explanation: Holding h4 limits colourable legislation doctrine to constitutionally restricted legislatures, directly addressing i4 claim of invalidity due to naked confiscation in Commutation Regulation provisions

anchor.surface_text: The doctrine of invalidity of legislative provisions enacted in colourable exercise of authority applies to legislatures whose powers are subject to constitutional restrictions. When such a legislative body seeks, under the guise or pretence of complying with the restrictions, in enacting a statute, to evade or elude them, it is but a fraud on the Constitution, and the statute is liable to be declared invalid on the ground that the enactment is in colourable exercise of authority, the statute being in truth beyond the competence of the body. But a statute enacted by a legislative authority whose powers are not fettered by any constitutional or other limitations, cannot be declared invalid as enacted in colourable exercise of its powers.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with costs. Civil Appeal No. 686 of 1957. This appeal raises the same question which has been decided in the companion Appeal No.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with costs. Civil Appeal No. 686 of 1957. This appeal raises the same question which has been decided in the companion Appeal No.

The Constitution has except as otherwise expressly provided, no retrospective operation Keshavan Madhava Menon v. State of Bombay 1 and rights which were by legislation extinguished, before it was enacted, are not revived thereby. At the commencement of the Constitution, the appellant had, therefore, no rights in the jagirs and he, obviously, could not claim a writ of mandamus directing delivery of possession of the jagir, or a writ directing commutation otherwise than under the provisions of the Commutation Regulation.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with costs. Civil Appeal No. 686 of 1957. This appeal raises the same question which has been decided in the companion Appeal No.

anchor.surface_text: It may also be observed that the Parliament has, by the Constitution 1st, Amendment Act, included the Abolition and the Commutation Regulations in the ninth schedule, and by virtue of Art. 31 B , the two Regulations are exempt from challenge on the ground that they are inconsistent with or take away or abridge any of the fundamental rights conferred by Part III of the Constitution.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with costs. Civil Appeal No. 686 of 1957. This appeal raises the same question which has been decided in the companion Appeal No.
